headline: Gambia Voted To Oust Its Dictator, But He Isn't Going Quietly
short descr: Fears are growing over what will happen when Yahya Jammeh's presidency expires this week.
image_caption(s): Gambian President Yahya Jammeh attends a rally in Banjul, Gambia, on Nov. 29, 2016. After losing the presidential election on Dec. 1, he attempted to challenge the election results in court and has refused to concede to his opponent, Adama Barrow.
article: The small West African nation of Gambia is rapidly approaching a crucial deadline. On Thursday, authoritarian President Yahya Jammehâ€™s 23-year-long rule is set to end after his unexpected election defeat last month.But there is little indication that Jammeh intends to give up power. Instead, he declared a state of emergency on Tuesday after weeks of attempting to contest the result of the vote.Jammehâ€™s refusal to step down in the wake of his countryâ€™s Dec. 1 election now threatens to plunge Gambia into turmoil and create an international crisis. Regional powers have been making preparations in recent weeks for a possible military intervention to force him from office.The Economic Community of West African States bloc has put troops on standby ahead of Jan. 19, the day Jammehâ€™s mandate expires, and Nigeria has reportedly deployed a warship to Gambiaâ€™s coast to put pressure on Jammeh. With a population of just under two million people, Gambia has only a tiny fraction of other West African countriesâ€™ military capacity. The current situation represents a stark change from last month, when Gambians celebrated in the streets after electing businessman Adama Barrow to the presidency. After the election, Jammeh stated he would respect the result, but he changed his mind less than two weeks later. He has since moved to seize election offices, arrested protesters and launched a failed bid to challenge the election in Gambiaâ€™s Supreme Court. The president of the election commission fled the country out of concern for his safety earlier this month, as have hundreds of Gambian citizens worried about possible violence.President-elect Barrow also left the country for security reasons, and is now in neighboring Senegal. On Sunday, a dog mauled Barrowâ€™s young son to death in Gambia, but he was unable to return to the country for the funeral.Human rights groups fear that the humanitarian situation in Gambia could further decline if the crisis isnâ€™t resolved soon. Last spring, protests against Jammehâ€™s rule led his government to imprison and kill members of the political opposition. Another crackdown could lead to violence and force more Gambians to flee as refugees.â€œThere is a history in Gambia of protests being brutally repressed,â€ Stephen Cockburn, Amnesty Internationalâ€™s deputy regional director for West and Central Africa, told The WorldPost. â€œProtests being faced down by an army who are using live ammunition is one of the biggest risks over the coming weeks.â€Jammehâ€™s state of emergency bans â€œacts intended to disturb public orderâ€ and â€œacts of disobedience.â€ â€œThe declared State of Emergency must not be used to crackdown on peaceful dissent, and the security forces must not take this as a green light to repress those who may wish to speak out,â€ Cockburn wrote in an email.Jammehâ€™s refusal to step down has left him facing greater political isolation both internationally and at home. A number of Gambian officials resigned this week, including top ministers and the mayor of the capital city of Banjul. The African Union stated that it will not recognize Jammehâ€™s legitimacy after his term runs out.â€œRegional leaders have long been fed up with Yahya Jammehâ€ said Jeffrey Smith, founder of nonprofit advocacy group Vanguard Africa, which supported Barrowâ€™s campaign. â€œThe Gambia really has become an outlier in the region and a pariah state,â€ he added.Jammeh originally seized power in a 1994 coup, and human rights groups have repeatedly condemned his rule for violently repressing dissent. He once said he would slit the throats of gay men in his country and claimed he could cure HIV. After elections in 2011, Jammeh claimed he would rule for a billion years if it was Godâ€™s will.

headline: Russians Mint 'In Trump We Trust' Coin Ahead Of U.S. Inauguration
short descr: The coins come in both silver and gold, with a cherubic image of the incoming president.
image_caption(s): A Russian company has revealed a commemorative Donald Trump coin ahead of this week's Inauguration.
article: Hereâ€™s some money thatâ€™s definitely funny.A Russian company has unveiled commemorative silver and gold coins featuring Donald Trumpâ€™s face ahead of his presidential inauguration.The limited-edition coins â€• only 45 have been made â€• feature a cherubic mug of the incoming president as well as the Statue of Liberty and the inscription: â€œIn Trump We Trust.â€ Vladimir Vasyukhin, director of the metal-works company Art-Grani, recently showcased the nearly two-pound medallion to The Associated Press Television Network.â€œThere are more hopes associated with Trump with regards to the lifting of sanctions; maybe the environment (between the U.S. and Russia) will change,â€ Vasyukhin told the network, explaining his motivation.Trump has indeed suggested such a rosy outlook. He has praised Russian President Vladimir Putin as a strong leader who is â€œvery smart.â€ That comes despite contrasting comments from U.S. politicians as well as U.S. intelligence agencies suggesting that Russia was behind hackings that interfered with the presidential election. Earlier this month, the CIA, FBI and National Security Agency concluded that Moscow was directly responsible for the attacks.In an interview released Monday, Trump suggested relaxing some U.S. sanctions against Russia â€” imposed over its annexation of Crimea â€” if the nation agrees to a nuclear arms reduction.Vasyukhin, who said the coins will sell for thousands of dollars, said his company would like to give the first coin to the president-elect himself. He said his company has asked Russian diplomats and business partners to help arrange the presentation.Art-Graniâ€™s prior work includes coins featuring Putinâ€™s face. One such coin was reportedly crafted to celebrate the annexation of Crimea, which Ukraineâ€™s then-prime minister had decried as â€œa robbery on an international scale.â€

headline: A Border Wall Like Steve Kingâ€™s Model Could Be Dangerous For U.S. Agents
short descr: If youâ€™re going to build a wall, do it right.
image_caption(s): This section of border fencing in Nogales, Arizona, is built of a series of metal beams, which allows Border Patrol agents to see through it.
article: One of Americaâ€™s toughest immigration hard-liners apparently keeps a model of a border wall in his office.Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa) tweeted a photo Friday that showed the model, as well as retired Gen. John Kelly, President-elect Donald Trumpâ€™s nominee for secretary of homeland security, with whom King was meeting.Hopefully Kelly seeks out other opinions. The model in Kingâ€™s photo appears to feature thick, opaque slabs topped with barbed wire. Itâ€™s visually impressive. But there would a big problem for anyone tasked with patrolling that wall: You canâ€™t see through it. Modern sections of wall erected along the U.S.-Mexico border are often made of thick steel beams called â€œbollards,â€ spaced at short intervals. This kind of barrier is more of a fence than a wall, but is just as difficult for a person to pass through. A fence may seem less grandiose than a wall, but itâ€™s more practical. If the wall is opaque, agents canâ€™t see whoâ€™s trying to cross. More importantly, they canâ€™t identify potential threats.In the days before the 2016 election, The Huffington Post took a tour of the border around Nogales, Arizona, with John Lawson, a veteran Border Patrol agent. Lawson told us that when he started out, the primitive fence was opaque. That was a liability for agents, and sometimes a hazard. In some instances, he said, assailants would scale the wall and try to drop cinder blocks on the agentsâ€™ vehicles as they passed below.â€œYou need to make a fence you can see through,â€ Lawson said â€• a remark that wasnâ€™t aimed at any public official in particular, and that occurred months before King tweeted his photo of the model wall.When U.S. Customs and Border Protection asked for funds last year to erect additional miles of barrier along the countryâ€™s southern border, it requested metal and concrete bollard fencing specifically, according to Reuters.Kingâ€™s office did not respond to a request for comment.The Iowa Republican has distinguished himself as a vocal opponent of immigration, advocating ideas like making English the official language of the United States and proposing legislation to end birthright citizenship.But his district lies several states and more than 1,000 miles away from the U.S.-Mexico border. Sometimes it shows.

headline: Colo, World's Oldest Known Gorilla, Dies At 60
short descr: She was reportedly the first gorilla born in a zoo.
image_caption(s): Colo as an infant, being held by the Columbus Zoo director's wife.
article: The worldâ€™s oldest known gorilla died in her sleep overnight, the Columbus Zoo announced Tuesday.Colo, a 60-year-old Western lowland gorilla, was the first gorilla ever born in a zoo, according to the Columbus Zoo. A necropsy is planned to determine Coloâ€™s cause of death, but the zoo notes that she had a malignant tumor removed under her arm on Dec. 3.Colo, whose name was short for â€œColumbus, Ohio,â€ had just celebrated her 60th birthday on Dec. 22, which zookeepers rang in with a gifts and a cake made out of apples and tomatoes. â€œShe was the coolest animal Iâ€™ve ever worked with and caring for her was the highlight of my career,â€ assistant curator Audra Meinelt said in the zooâ€™s statement. â€œIt was not just about what she meant for the gorilla community but for whom she was as a a gorilla. Iâ€™m heartbroken but also grateful for the 19 years I had with Colo.â€The average lifespan of a Western lowland gorilla in the wild is 35 years, according to National Geographic. And although gorillas in captivity may have longer lifespans, some primatologists and animal advocates question whether the large, intelligent creatures ethically can be kept in zoos at all.Primatologist Sarah Bluffer Hrdy told The New York Times in June that she has to â€œturn offâ€ her feelings when she goes to a zoo.â€œOtherwise, I canâ€™t really justify keeping great apes in cages,â€ she said.Colo is the second Ohio zoo gorilla to die this month. Bebac, a 32-year-old western lowland gorilla at the Cleveland Zoo, died of heart disease on Jan. 6.

headline: 'Lucky' Puppy Survives After Swallowing 8-Inch Knife Whole
short descr: "Her saving grace was that she swallowed the handle-end first."
image_caption(s): Irene Paisley and her puppy Macie, left, with an X-ray of the 8-inch cook's knife that the dog swallowed at her home in Glasgow, Scotland.
article: Macie the puppy is lucky to be alive after she swallowed a chefâ€™s knife.Frightening X-rays show how the 8-inch utensil became firmly lodged inside the 12-week-old Staffordshire bull terrierâ€™s stomach, intestines and gullet after she ingested it at her home in Glasgow, Scotland, three weeks ago. The dogâ€™s owner, Irene Paisley, said she initially didnâ€™t realize what was wrong with her pup when it began vomiting and then choking.â€œI was terrified,â€ Paisley said Tuesday, adding that blood later shot out of the animalâ€™s nose.She rushed Macie to the Peopleâ€™s Dispensary for Sick Animals (PDSA) emergency out-of-hours veterinarian service. Veterinarians X-rayed the dog, discovered the blade and performed emergency surgery to remove it. â€œIâ€™ve never seen an X-ray like Macieâ€™s,â€ veterinarian Emily Ronald said. â€œShe was extremely lucky to survive. Her saving grace was that she swallowed the handle-end first â€• the blade-end would undoubtedly have pierced her organs, likely causing fatal injuries.â€Paisley said she had â€œno ideaâ€ how her pet had gotten hold of the knife. â€œShe could have pinched it out of the dishwasher, but no one saw what happened,â€ the mom of four said in a statement.Macie, meanwhile, is now back at home and expected to make a full recovery.

headline: China Warns Donald Trump Against Pulling U.S. Out Of Paris Climate Pact
short descr: Chinese President Xi Jinping called it a â€œhard-won achievementâ€ that â€œall signatories should stick to.â€
image_caption(s): Chinese President Xi Jinping attends the World Economic Forum annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.
article: Without mentioning Donald Trump by name, Chinese President Xi Jinping on Tuesday urged the president-elect to keep the United States in the historic Paris climate pact â€• an accord Trump has promised to â€œcancel.â€ Last year, more than 170 countries pledged to drastically reduce carbon emissions in an effort to limit the rise in global temperatures. Speaking Tuesday at the World Economic Forumâ€™s annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, Xi called the pact a â€œhard-won achievementâ€ that â€œall signatories should stick to.â€He stressed that tackling climate change is a responsibility we owe to future generations, and that walking away could have serious global consequences.â€œIt is important to protect the environment while pursuing economic and social progress â€• to achieve harmony between man and nature, and harmony between man society,â€ Xi said.Trump, a longtime climate-change skeptic who has dismissed the phenomenon as â€œbullshitâ€ and a Chinese â€œhoax,â€ has promised to pull the U.S. out of the Paris climate agreement â€• a promise that did not sit well with hundreds of the worldâ€™s leading scientists or Americaâ€™s business community.In September, U.S. President Barack Obama and Xi fortified commitments to reduce carbon emissions by formally joining the Paris agreement and pledging a â€œcontinued bilateral climate cooperation.â€ The U.S. and China are the worldâ€™s two largest emitters of greenhouse gases.As China continues its push to rein in the use of fossil fuels, most recently with an announcement to invest $361 billion into renewable energy generation by 2020, Trump has given new life to Americaâ€™s oil and gas industry. He has vowed to increase Americaâ€™s production of coal, oil and natural gas, as well as do away with Obama administration regulations aimed at cutting emissions.In what appeared to be a clear swing at Trumpâ€™s â€œAmerica Firstâ€ policies, Xi defended free trade and warned countries to â€œrefrain from pursuing their own interests at the expense of others.â€â€œWe must promote trade and investment, liberalization and facilitation through opening up â€• and say no to protectionism,â€ he said Tuesday. â€œNo one will emerge as a winner in a trade war.â€The World Economic Forum noted in a press release that since Trumpâ€™s surprise victory, â€œChina has emerged as a potential new leader on the global stage â€• and todayâ€™s address does little to soften the impression that President Xi is taking an increasingly assertive stance on matters of global trade and climate change.â€Since his election, Trump has repeatedly clashed with China, which he has promised to get tough on. In November, Chinaâ€™s Vice Foreign Minister Liu Zhenmin took on Trumpâ€™s claim that climate change is a Chinese â€œhoax,â€ saying it was Republican U.S. Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush â€• not the Chinese â€• who started the conversation about global warming. Trump sparked controversy in December when he spoke by phone with Taiwanâ€™s president Tsai Ying-wen, breaking decades of U.S. policy with China, which claims sovereignty over the island. He has also questioned why the United States must be bound by the â€œone Chinaâ€ policy. A state-run Chinese newspaper called Trump â€œas ignorant as a childâ€ in response. The president-elect, who takes office Friday, also slammed China for its seizure of a U.S. underwater drone in the South China Sea last month, calling it an â€œunpresidented [sic] act.â€

headline: Topless Protester In Spain Grabs Waxwork Donald Trump's Crotch
short descr: Feminist organization FEMEN has claimed credit for the incident, which was caught on camera.
image_caption(s): A topless feminist activist grabbed a Donald Trump waxwork in the crotch area during its unveiling at the Madrid Wax Museum on Tuesday.
article: A topless feminist protester groped a waxwork of Donald Trump during its official unveiling in Madrid, Spain, on Tuesday morning.The unidentified woman, who had â€œgrab backâ€ and â€œgrab patriarchy by the ballsâ€ scrawled in English across her bare chest and back, reportedly broke through a security cordon to grab the crotch area of the life-sized statue of the U.S. president-elect. Video footage posted online shows her repeatedly yelling out â€œgrab patriarchy by the ballsâ€ in both English and Spanish, while trying to evade detention by an official at the Madrid Wax Museum.Soon after, the woman was escorted away and removed from the building, according to Spanish media reports. Itâ€™s unclear whether she will face police action. The Huffington Post has reached out for more information.The Spanish branch of the global feminist organization FEMEN â€• which similarly disrupted Trumpâ€™s polling station in midtown Manhattan, New York City, on Election Day â€” later claimed credit for the incident.â€œFEMEN just grabbed Trumpâ€™s statue by the balls in Madrid,â€ it posted on Twitter in a clear reference to Trumpâ€™s sickening hot mic comments made alongside then-â€Access Hollywoodâ€ host Billy Bush in 2005. While footage of the incident went viral, the museumâ€™s press chief described the womanâ€™s protest as â€œunpleasant.â€â€œIf they want to do this, they should do it directly to him,â€ Gonzalo Presa told Reuters. â€œThis is too easy.â€The museum is now beefing up its general security, a spokesman told the Europa Press news agency. â€œNot just for Trump,â€ he said, but because â€œnowadays things occur that didnâ€™t used to occur.â€

headline: Puerto Rican Nationalist Granted Clemency After Decades In Prison
short descr: Oscar LÃ³pez Rivera spent 35 years in prison, having never been convicted of a violent act. In May, he'll be free.
image_caption(s): People march to demand the release of Puerto Rican nationalist Oscar Lopez Rivera near the White House in Washington, DC, on Jan. 11, 2017. Obama granted him clemency in his last week of office.
article: President Barack Obama commuted the sentence of Puerto Rican nationalist leader Oscar LÃ³pez Rivera on Tuesday, in a move cheered by activists on and off the island who had pressed for years to have his decades-long sentence cut short.  LÃ³pez Rivera spent 35 years in prison â€• including 12 years in solitary confinement â€• for his role in the Armed Forces of National Liberation, a Puerto Rican independence group active during the 1970s and 1980s. The group, known by its Spanish initials as FALN, committed violent acts including bombings, killings and kidnappings. But LÃ³pez Rivera was himself convicted of seditious conspiracy rather than an act of violence. The group was responsible for six deaths, according to Puerto Rican daily El Nuevo DÃ­a, but renounced violence altogether in 1983.Puerto Rican leaders across the political spectrum have for years advocated for his release, viewing him as a political prisoner who poses no threat to the United States. â€œI am overjoyed and overwhelmed with emotion,â€ U.S. Rep. Luis GutiÃ©rrez (D-Ill.) said in a statement. â€œOscar is a friend, a mentor, and family to me and he and his brother JosÃ© have been friends and mentors for my entire adult life. There were times when hope was hard to find but my wife Soraida always had faith that this day would come. Now it is clear that Oscar will rejoin his family and be able to walk free among the Puerto Rican people.â€Other prominent Americans of Puerto Rican heritage issued similarly joyful statements, including â€œHamiltonâ€ creator Lin-Manuel Miranda, who tweeted: LÃ³pez Rivera, who is now 74 and currently jailed at Terre Haute in Indiana, will be freed in 120 days. He continues to question U.S. control of Puerto Rico, an island governed as a U.S. territory, but whose residents cannot cast a ballot for president or send a voting member to Congress. â€œHow can a Puerto Rican be seditious towards the U.S. state when we never had any part in electing a U.S. government?â€ LÃ³pez Rivera said in an interview with The Guardian in October.  Rivera plans to settle in the Puerto Rican town of San SebastiÃ¡n, where he was born, El Nuevo DÃ­a reports. The news Tuesday came the same day as a round of more than 200 other commutations, including one for Chelsea Manning, the U.S. army soldier who was imprisoned for releasing classified documents to WikiLeaks.

headline: Mystery As Dozens Of Dolphins Die In Florida Everglades Stranding
short descr: â€œIn the coming months biologists will try to determine why this happened."
image_caption(s): Nearly 100 false killer whales beached themselves in the Florida Everglades over the weekend. Most of them have died.
article: Wildlife officials in southwest Florida are trying to determine why nearly 100 false killer whales stranded themselves over the weekend in the Everglades National Park. The U.S. Coast Guard first discovered the heartbreaking scene in Hog Key Saturday morning. As of late Monday, 82 of the 95 animals, which are a type of dolphin, have died. Thirteen are unaccounted for, the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration Fisheries announced.â€œIn the coming months biologists will try to determine why this happened by using samples collected during necropsy (non-human autopsy),â€ the organization stated in a release. At a press conference Monday, Blair Mase of NOAA Fisheries detailed the rescue efforts.â€œOnce on scene, a response team attempted to herd some of the free swimming live whales into deeper water, however, they were ultimately unsuccessful with that effort,â€ Mase said. â€œThe whales that were beached were scattered and spread out all along the shoreline and deeply embedded into the mangroves making response efforts extremely difficult.â€False killer whales, which can grow up to 20 feet in length, get their name from their resemblance to orcas. They are extremely social animals and form tight pods that are known to strand themselves, according to the NOAA Fisheries website.This is only the third known false killer whale stranding in Florida, Mase said.In 1986, 28 dolphins stranded themselves in Key West. Three years later, in 1989, another pod needed to be rescued near Tampa. Mass strandings of the species have also occurred in Australia and Argentina, Mase said. False killer whales are listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act.Authorities have closed the surrounding area and are requesting no flyovers or boats for safety reasons.CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article misidentified the location of Hog Key, which is along Floridaâ€™s southwest coast.

headline: Gene Cernan, Last Man To Walk On The Moon, Has Died
short descr: The retired Navy commander, 82, never forgot the "overpowering beauty of the Earth."
image_caption(s): Cernan's crew captured this iconic "blue marble" shot of the Earth en route to the moon.
article: The last man in the world to take one of the most historic jaunts in human history has died. Astronaut Gene Cernan, who walked on the moon in 1972 and ended the astonishing adventure with a message of peace and hope, died at the age of 82 surrounded by his family, according to a statement NASA released Monday. â€œOur family is heartbroken, of course, and we truly appreciate everyoneâ€™s thoughts and prayers. Gene, as he was known by so many, was a loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend,â€ Cernanâ€™s family said in a statement, CNN reported. His death was attributed to unspecified ongoing health issues.The retired Navy captain remained an indefatigable fighter for the space program and for other humans to have the opportunities to experience what he had. â€œWhen I leave this planet, I want to know where we are headed as a nation. Thatâ€™s my big goal,â€ he testified before Congress in 2011.His experience in space changed his life profoundly. â€œI can always walk on Main Street again, but I can never return to my Valley of Taurus-Littrow [on the moon], and that cold fact has left me with a yearning restlessness,â€ he wrote in his 1999 autobiography, The Last Man on the Moon.â€œIt was perhaps the brightest moment of my life, and I canâ€™t go back,â€ he added. â€œEnriched by a singular event that is larger than life, I no longer have the luxury of being ordinary.â€Cernan was a member of a very exclusive club of only a dozen men who have set foot on the moon. He and his partner, astronaut-geologist Harrison â€œJackâ€ Schmitt, were the only two men ever to sing on the lunar surface.Cernan, the commander of NASAâ€™s Apollo 17 mission, stepped onto the moon on Dec. 14, 1972, during his third flight into space. En route to the moon, the three-man crew captured the iconic â€œblue marbleâ€ photo of the Earth showing Africa, the Arabian peninsula and the south polar ice cap.Cernan called the landing â€œthe most quiet moment a human being can experience in his lifetime.â€ Thereâ€™s â€œno vibration. Thereâ€™s no noise. The ground quit talking,â€ he recalled in a 2007 oral history recorded by NASA. â€œThe dust is gone. Itâ€™s a realization, a reality, all of a sudden you have just landed in another world on another body out there [in the] universe, and what you are seeing is being seen by ... human eyes for the first time.â€He and Schmitt spent spent some 22 hours on the lunar surface over three days, collecting 250 pounds of moon samples. â€œIn that whole three days, I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anything that became routine,â€ Cernan recalled. â€œBut if I had to focus on one thing ... it was just to look back at the overwhelming and overpowering beauty of this Earth. I wished I could have stayed awake for 75 hours straight. I knew when I left Iâ€™d never have a chance to come back.â€The final steps up the ladder back to the Challenger lunar module â€œwere tough to make,â€ he added. â€œI didnâ€™t want to go up. I wanted to stay a while. Itâ€™s like you would want to freeze that moment and take it home with you. But you canâ€™t.â€As he returned he said: â€œAmericaâ€™s challenge of today has forged manâ€™s destiny of tomorrow. As we leave the moon, we leave as we came, and, God willing, we shall return, with peace and hope for all mankind.â€Cernan was born in Chicago in 1934 and graduated from Indianaâ€™s Purdue University in 1956. He became a Navy attack pilot before being selected for NASAâ€™s astronaut program in 1963. Three years later, he became the second American to walk in space during a Gemini 9 flight â€• something he called the â€œspacewalk from hellâ€ because of several malfunctions in his spacesuit. He logged a total of 566 hours and 15 minutes in space, more than 73 hours of which were on the moonâ€™s surface, either in the module or on the ground. Cernan eventually retired from NASA in 1976.Cernanâ€™s last action on the surface of the moon in 1972 was to trace â€œTDCâ€ â€” the initials of his then-9-year-old daughter, Teresa Dawn â€” in the lunar dust. He said he imagined someone in the far distant future would find â€œour lunar rover and our footprints and those initials and say, â€˜I wonder who was here? Some ancient civilization was here back in the 20th century, and look at the funny marks they made.â€™â€CORRECTION: A previous version of this article said Cernan was born in 1935. He was born in 1934.

headline: You Can Help Rebuild A Mosque That Was Burned Down In America
short descr: Members of the Seattle area mosque are "overwhelmed" by the support so far. But they need more.
image_caption(s): The Islamic Center of Eastside was destroyed by fire early Saturday morning.
article: His mosque was burned to the ground in the early morning hours of Saturday, but on Sunday night his heart was full of hope. â€œWe are so overwhelmed,â€ said Imam Fazal Hassan, looking out over the crowd inside Sammamish High School in Bellevue, Washington. Some 400 people had gathered there to show support for the local Muslim community, according to mosque board member Tanvir Rahman. Hassan recounted how immediately after news spread that his mosque â€• the Islamic Center of Eastside in Bellevue â€• had been destroyed by fire, he received calls from the areaâ€™s rabbis, priests and pastors, all offering to help.Outside the mosque, Hassan said, other non-Muslims in the Seattle area left gifts: flowers, balloons and cookies. â€œThey were still warm!â€ Hassan said of the cookies, and the crowd burst into laughter. Hassan then cited a hadith â€• â€œHe who does not thank people, does not thank Allahâ€ â€• before thanking the townâ€™s mayor, the fire chief, the police chief, the FBI and everyone else in the Bellevue area â€œfrom the bottom of my heart.â€â€œI thank you for all the support, love and compassion and respect you have been giving us,â€ he said. The crowd rose to their feet in applause. (You can see the imamâ€™s remarks on video shot by an audience member here.)It was a moving moment, Rahman told The Huffington Post, and still more moving to know that the Islamic Center has already raised over $200,000 in donations on LaunchGood toward building a new mosque. Thatâ€™s almost halfway to the $500,000 goal. â€œWe are extremely, extremely humbled by the show of support and acceptance,â€ Rahman said. (You can donate here.) â€œIâ€™m shaking in tears and shock right now,â€ Varisha Khan, a senior at the University of Washington, wrote in a Facebook post on Saturday after watching a video of her childhood mosque in flames.â€œThis was my second home after moving to Seattle and so much of my identity was shaped from the amazing people, experiences, memories, lessons, and standing shoulder-to-shoulder in prayers here for nearly a decade of my life,â€ she wrote. Police have arrested 37-year-old Isaac Wayne Wilson in connection with the fire, Bellevue Police Chief Steve Mylett told reporters at a press conference on Saturday.After responding to the blaze at 2:44 a.m., police officers discovered Wilson lying down in a nearby parking lot. Mylett said Wilson, who is homeless, made statements to officers that implicated him in the alleged arson. There is also video evidence, Mylett said. Wilson was also wanted on a warrant in Seattle for malicious mischief. According to The Seattle Times, Hassan, the imam, said Wilson had visited the mosque last year and said he wanted to pray, but he was asked to leave after creating a disturbance and using profanities.Speaking at Saturdayâ€™s press conference, a King County assistant prosecuting attorney said he expected his office to charge Wilson with second-degree arson on Tuesday. Prosecutor Mike Hogan added there is no evidence yet that the fire was a hate crime.In a Facebook post, the Washington state chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) asked people to â€œnot jump to conclusionsâ€ about Wilsonâ€™s motive. Nonetheless, mosques in the area have been targeted in the recent past.Earlier this month, 36-year-old Kamal Samater was arrested and charged with malicious harassment, a hate crime, for allegedly telling a man in the Islamic Center of Eastside parking lot that he was â€œgoing to assassinate everyoneâ€ at the mosque. â€œThere is no place in America for Muslims,â€ Samater allegedly said. In the nearby community of Redmond, the Muslim Association of Puget Sound has had its sign vandalized twice in the last few months. Police are investigating those incidents as hate crimes. In June, after the Orlando, Florida, night club shooting, Redmond police received anonymous phone calls threatening people who worship at the Islamic Center of Puget Sound. A report last year from the Center for the Study of Hate and Extremism at California State University, San Bernardino, tallied at least 260 hate crimes targeting Muslims across the country in 2015. Thatâ€™s nearly an 80 percent rise from 2014 and the greatest number of such crimes in any year since 2001. Mosques were targeted for vandalism, arson and other types of destruction 80 times in 2015, according to a report from CAIR. Thatâ€™s a jump of nearly 400 percent from the year before.HuffPost also found nearly 400 acts of anti-Muslim violence, discrimination and political speech in the U.S. so far in 2016.Farida Hakim, a founding member of the Islamic Center of Eastside, told HuffPost that her â€œheart is overwhelmed with the love and support of our neighborsâ€ since the fire. She said she was especially moved by a letter that a woman dropped off at the mosque Saturday, along with a $20 donation.â€œPlease donâ€™t let the actions of one person (or a nation of people who are ignorant and spiteful for that matter) make you feel unsafe or welcome,â€ the letter read. The Huffington Post is documenting the rising wave of anti-Muslim bigotry and violence in America. Take a stand against hate.

headline: Even 'The Bachelor' Can't Hide From Female Solidarity Forever
authors: Claire Fallon, Emma Gray, and Nick Offenberg
short descr: #LeanIn to making friends, not drama, in the Bachelor mansion.
image_caption(s): Could all these women actually be here to empower each other? Maybe.
article: Certain places exist where one simply shouldnâ€™t go to fulfill oneâ€™s yen for egalitarian, socially conscious television.For example, â€œThe Bachelor.â€ Yet on Monday nightâ€™s episode of Nick Viallâ€™s season, telltale signs emerged that the franchise has been infected by something antithetical to its very nature: feminism.For 21 seasons, the entire concept of the show has been to exploit womenâ€™s social conditioning to compete with each other for male approval and attention, translating the resulting tension into high ratings. At the end, an appropriately feminine, beautiful, and (ideally) demure lady wins the manâ€™s hand in marriage. (Sure, â€œThe Bacheloretteâ€ exists, and flipping the roles is great, but it simply doesnâ€™t play off the same long-entrenched gender scripts that the original show does.)Many feminist viewers, including myself, have argued that this rigidly traditional lens is part of the allure of the show: It allows us to critique real gender norms and dating-world absurdities in a comically overblown setting. Though we critique the showâ€™s sexist flaws, I, at least, have never dreamed of a feminist â€œBachelor.â€ By its very nature, the show is anti-feminist; itâ€™s coded into the franchise DNA. A feminist â€œBachelorâ€ would be no â€œBachelorâ€ at all. (Maybe it would be â€œCoupled.â€)The men and women who compete on the show, however, can change with the times. Last season on â€œThe Bachelorette,â€ contestant Derek Peth chided villain Chad Johnson for his â€œmisogynistic commentsâ€ â€• using a word almost unheard-of on the franchise, though the concept is everywhere in evidence. Even this season on â€œThe Bachelor,â€ usually the format wherein producers are best able to play women against each other for male approval and TV gold, the women have been fairly supportive of each other.Of course, thereâ€™s the necessary villain. Corinne, the 24-year-old self-described business owner with a nanny, has carved out a classic arc as the â€œsluttyâ€ femme fatale who demands all of Nickâ€™s attention at the expense of the other women. The first couple of episodes, her tactics â€• making out with him during their first conversation, taking her top off during a photo shoot with Nick â€• drew some dismissive and slut-shaming comments from other contestants. Corinne, for her part, has plenty of misogynistic comments for other women in the house, and even herself. (It was pretty sad, for me, to hear how convinced she is that approaching a man naked with whipped cream on her breasts is the only way she could truly capture his attention.)During the third episode, however, the contestants mostly chose to handle the kerfuffle surrounding this storyline with female solidarity. Jasmine watched the younger woman pout through a date featuring the Backstreet Boys, then learned she has a nanny named Raquel who makes her bed and prepares her lunches. Finally, Jasmine announced to the camera that sheâ€™d slap Nick if he gave Corinne a rose after how sheâ€™d behaved. Violence isnâ€™t the most enlightened response (for the record, no such slap occurred), but itâ€™s somewhat heartening to see the women question their potential partnerâ€™s behavior and dating preferences rather than directly turning on their so-called competition. Later, Corinne and Nick hooked up in a bouncy castle (really) while the other women were nearby enjoying a pool party, and his antics became known. A bouncy castle isnâ€™t exactly a private spot. The tipping point had been reached, and one by one, women began initiating confrontations â€• not with Corinne, as often happens with â€œBachelorâ€ villains, but with Nick. Vanessa made the issue most explicit, telling him, â€œIâ€™m not judging Corinne. Iâ€™m judging your actions.â€ It had left her questioning whether he just wanted to fool around, and she put that on him, not on another woman. It sounds simple, but itâ€™s deeply ingrained in women to blame other women, not men, for their infidelity or wandering eyes. While weâ€™ve seen bromances before on â€œThe Bachelorette,â€ and a few close female friendships, the general atmosphere in Nickâ€™s house of bachelorettes seems unusually and admirably supportive. Aside from Corinne, the women appear to get along â€• they even appear to be pleasant to Corinne. On the second episode, she attempts to goad 23-year-old mental health counselor Taylor into a spat over time spent with Nick on a group date, but Taylor calmly refuses to get upset. (In previews, we see that this will start to devolve, but a gallant effort at staying friendly was made.) On Episode 3, Dominique realizes sheâ€™s failed to garner much attention from the Bachelor, and on her group date, she becomes emotional. Rachel, a frontrunner, pulls her aside and comforts her, giving her solid advice on calming down and making the most of her time with the man theyâ€™re supposedly competing for. Dominique then stumbles upon Rachel making out with Nick â€• and despite her clearly rampant insecurity and envy, she doesnâ€™t succumb to an impulse to trash her rival. Instead, she says that itâ€™s hard to see, but sheâ€™s happy for Rachel.At least part of this is likely just the individual crop of women. Itâ€™s a kind, classy bunch! But in Vanessaâ€™s pointed remark that sheâ€™s not judging Corinne, but is looking to see whether Nick wants the same things she does, thereâ€™s a clear consciousness of what female solidarity means.The mutually supportive, empowering spirit among the women remaining in the house (well, most of them) suggests sheâ€™s not alone. Whether these bachelorettes came here to make friends or not, theyâ€™re not here to hurt other women. Thatâ€™s pretty refreshing.For more on â€œThe Bachelor,â€ listen to HuffPostâ€™s podcast â€œHere to Make Friendsâ€ below:Do people love â€œThe Bachelor,â€ â€œThe Bacheloretteâ€ and â€œBachelor in Paradise,â€ or do they love to hate these shows? Itâ€™s unclear. But here at â€œHere to Make Friends,â€ we both love and love to hate them â€” and we love to snarkily dissect each episode in vivid detail. Podcast edited by Nick Offenberg.Want more â€œBachelorâ€ stories in your life? The newsletter will also serve you up some juicy celeb news, hilarious late-night bits, awards coverage and more. Sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: Politicians Honor MLK Day While Working Against The Rights He Fought For
short descr: If your policies lead to voter suppression, you're not actually fighting for justice.
image_caption(s): Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker (R) speaks during the third day of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, July 20, 2016.
article: Politicians across the U.S. marked Martin Luther King Jr. Day this year by sharing photos of the civil rights hero and remembering his fight for equality. Some of the people paying tribute did so despite having actively fought against the causes that Dr. King championed.Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker (R), for one, has been a staunch advocate for voter ID laws. Such laws tend to disenfranchise people of color and low-income Americans, who are less likely to carry the right kind of identification. Proponents of such measures say that they help combat voter fraud, a problem that is both rare and largely not possible to prevent with voter ID laws. Critics of voter ID laws, including former Attorney General Eric Holder, compare them to poll taxes, which Dr. King marched against.Still, Walker tweeted on Monday that he was honoring â€œthe life and legacyâ€ of King.Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R) also paid tribute to King, despite his own voter suppression controversies. Scott was criticized by civil rights advocates in the weeks leading up to the 2016 elections for refusing to extend the voter-registration deadline even with a hurricane looming over the state.â€œEverybody has had a lot of time to register,â€ Scott said. A federal judge soon reversed that decision, along with a Florida law that put strict standards on mail-in ballots. U.S. District Court Judge Mark Walker called the law an â€œundeclared war on Floridiansâ€™ right to vote.â€Ohio Gov. John Kasich (R), who in 2014 signed into law major restrictions on early voting, called on citizens to â€œembrace [Dr. Kingâ€™s] vision of equality, compassion, justice, and peace.â€Last year, under then-Gov. Mike Pence (R), Indiana state police raided a voter registration center working to sign up black citizens. Pence, who also opposed a state law banning LGBTQ workplace discrimination, tweeted about MLK Day too. Itâ€™s hard not to wonder what Dr. King, who once said that â€œwe must live together as brothers or perish together as fools,â€ would have thought about the vice president-electâ€™s record.President-elect Donald Trump and his real estate empire have a long history of discriminating against black tenants. In 1970s, the Justice Department actually sued Trump and his father, Fred, over allegations that they wouldnâ€™t allow African Americans to live in their apartment buildings. The case was settled out of court.Trump also infamously pledged to ban Muslims from entering the country, accused Mexico of sending â€œrapistsâ€ to the U.S. and has nominated for attorney general Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), a man who was once deemed too racist for a judgeship position. (Coretta Scott King, Dr. Kingâ€™s wife, even wrote a scathing letter opposing Sessionsâ€™ 1986 nomination.)Despite this, Trump, who has received the enthusiastic endorsement of white supremacists, urged Americans on Monday to celebrate King and â€œall of the many wonderful things that he stood for.â€
